columns.text: In this problem, we will look at the relationship of the change in cashflow to the degree of operating leverage which measures how much a company's revenue is changed by a certain change in the quantity of the units sold.

Substituting the known values, we will get the DOL:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{DOL}&=1+\dfrac{\$89,000}{\$127,400}\\[15 pt]
&=1+0.701\\[15 pt]
&=1.701
\end{aligned}$$

The DOL in this scenario is $1.701$

We can start by taking the percentage change in quantity:

$$\begin{aligned}
\Delta \text{Q}&=\dfrac{\text{new} -\text{old}}{\text{old}}\\
\end{aligned}$$

Substituting the values we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\Delta \text{Q}&=\dfrac{11,100-10,400}{10,400}\\[15 pt]
&=0.0673
\end{aligned}$$

There is a $0.0673$ or $6.73\%$ change in the quantity sold.

Using the DOL in the previous question, we can solve for the percentage change in operating cashflow:

$$\begin{aligned}
1.701&=\dfrac{\Delta \text{OCF}}{0.0673}\\
\end{aligned}$$

Cross multiply to get the percentage change in operating cashflow

$$\begin{aligned}
\Delta \text{OCF}&=1.701 \times 0.0673\\[15 pt]
&=0.114
\end{aligned}$$

There is a $0.114$ or $11.4\%$ increase in the operating cashflow

Now that we have the percentage change of the tow variables, we can then use the formula in Step 3:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{DOL}&=\dfrac{0.114}{0.0673}\\[15 pt]
&=1.694
\end{aligned}$$

The new DOL is $1.694$
